body:
I think this is a good approach, as highlighting all of the lines could lead to unclear guidance.

Iâ€™m personally ðŸ‘ on this suggestion, but before moving forward, Iâ€™d like to gather a few more thoughts from the team. @eslint/eslint-team

> pretty small surface area

Is that really an issue? There are rules that highlight two characters (`?.`) so highlighting exactly the identifier here sounds appropriate, regardless of number of characters.

@fregante can you put together a proposal for what should be highlighted for all the different kinds of functions:

1. Function declarations
2. Function expressions (can be anonymous)
3. Arrow function expressions (always anonymous)
4. Object methods
5. Class methods

I'd suggest looking through other function-related rules to see how they handle these situations.

> I'd suggest looking through other function-related rules to see how they handle these situations.

From a quick look, the behavior described here is the standard:

- https://eslint.org/docs/latest/rules/func-name-matching
- https://eslint.org/docs/latest/rules/func-style
- https://eslint.org/docs/latest/rules/max-lines-per-function
- https://eslint.org/docs/latest/rules/max-statements

With this being a more moderate highlight:

- https://eslint.org/docs/latest/rules/func-names

And finally this matching what I want `complexity` to look like:

- https://eslint.org/docs/latest/rules/max-params

So maybe I'd suggest extracting a `reportFunction` utility from `max-params` and reuse it in `complexity` (and other rules that are similarly noisy)

Yep, this is pretty much what I had in mind: 1. highlight name 2. highlight `function` 3. highlight `=>` [](https://eslint.org/play/#)
Thanks for digging into that. I agree, I think those are good patterns and match what we already have. Let's do it!

@nzakas , @fregante 

Hey guys, is anyone working on this ?? If not, I am interested
